57

airlifts

Irma

Emergency rations and kits for World Food Programme, Catholic Relief Services, CARE, loaded and flying to #Haiti.

In addition to tarpaulins and hygiene items, the cargo contains enough High-Energy Biscuits to feed some 47,000 people for three days – these rations are suitable for use in crises when the cooking of food may not be possible.

The flight was funded by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Vice-President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai, and organized by the International Humanitarian City - IHC under the chairmanship of Her Royal Highness Princess Haya Bint Al Hussein.

South Sudan

UNHRD continued its support of operations in South Sudan throughout 2017. The International Humanitarian City generously provided an airlift in late May, where partners sent tarpaulins, tents, kitchen sets, school kits for those in need.

View facebook post

Uganda

14,000 blankets, 3,500 kitchen sets, and more Irish Aid life-saving items were airlifted to Entebbe for South Sudan Refugees.

Marking WorldRefugeeDay, 13.5 MT relief items from Cooperazione Italiana allo Sviluppo were airlifted to Uganda and further delivered to Rhino Camp, in North Uganda, which hosts refugees from South Sudan.

View facebook post View facebook post

Dubai team disassembled, checked and repacked over 750 ShelteBoxes. The cargo was split in two - half airlifted together with family kits and tarpaulins to Somalia and the other half went to Chad with blankets, jerry cans and mosquito nets.

Marawi

We are helping AHA CENTRE to airlift 42 metric tonnes of family tents and kits in response to the #MarawiCrisis. The lifesaving cargo is currently being loaded at UNHRD #KualaLumpur before heading to Davao airport #Philippines. More is on the way!  #HappeningNow

Mexico Earthquake

Cooperazione Italiana allo Sviluppo is sending blankets, tents, hygiene kits and kitchen sets to #Mexico from UNHRD #Brindisi. The items were dispatched in support of those affected by the recent earthquake.

Iran/Iraq earthquake

2 flights ex brindisi within 48 hours for Italy - Night-time loading operations at UNHRD #Brindisi for Cooperazione Italiana allo Sviluppo. The flight is bound for #Sulaymaniyah, #Iraq, carrying shelter and hygiene equipment for those affected by the #earthquake

Procurement

Over the course of 2017 UNHRD placed Procurement Orders for Goods and Services (excluding transport) with a total value of USD 20,698,423.39. Over 50% of procurement activities, whether replenishment of stock or direct delivery of goods, was for WFP Partners while the remainder was for non-WFP Partners and the requirements of UNHRD itself.

UNHRD Procurement strives to ensure a seamless pipeline of the core relief items and humanitarian support equipment required by our Partners, particularly those key items that are pre-positioned in our Hubs ready to deploy at short notice. This is achieved through the establishment and utilisation of Long Term Agreements, forward positioning of supplier stocks and careful monitoring of the supply chain. These activities also bring costs efficiencies for our Partners as we source the best value goods and maximise freight whenever possible. While logistics and staff support equipment have been the most procured items in 2017, beneficiary items such as tents, tarpaulins, hygiene kits, kitchen sets, blankets and family kits were also all in the “Top 15” items.

graphic over the years and logos of 2017 new partners

Thermal shield

This project aims to continue the development of the Thermal Shield- a passive thermal insulation solution that protects temperature sensitive products (such as SNF) during transportation and storage.

In 2016/2017 a Mercer University student team developed a small-scale model of the Thermal Shield and performed tests to this scaled model. Based on these testing results, the UNHRD LAB in conjecture with the student team at Mercer University think this could be a viable solution to shipping temperature sensitive products.

The next step of this project is to garner the needed materials to begin construction of the full-scale prototype. Following this step, tests will be performed regarding thermal efficiency and durability. Based on these tests, the UNHRD LAB will determine which parts of the solution need to be modified in order to create the best possible solution. After making these adjustments, further field testing will need to be completed. After completing this process, the final design will be determined. This solution will then be ready to be implemented during the transportation and storage of all temperature sensitive products, such as SNF. This solution will be communicated to all HRD locations and the humanitarian community in order to improve the quality of temperature sensitive products, and in turn, improve the health and welfare of individuals around the world.

first flight kit

The goal of this project is to create a ready-to-go accommodation and office kit for first responders to transport and construct during the first days of an emergency.

During 2016, UNHRD LAB finalized the development of a ready to go accommodation and office kit for the first responders to soon be tested in a sudden emergency. UNHRD will store the first two units in Brindisi and Dubai, and plan to preposition them in the remaining Hubs as well, to enable a more prompt/standardized procedure when responding to emergency. The next step of this project will be to test the prototype in the next emergency. First responders will use this kit to perform all necessary activities for three months. Based on this test, the UNHRD LAB will determine what parts of the solution need to be modified in order to create the most optimal first response kit.

The prototype will then be adjusted based off of these discoveries regarding: power supply, quality, performance, and practice. Therefore, the new kit will be updated with a self-sustainable power supply after the design and prototyping time frame. The design will be tested once more in the field. After going through this process, a final solution will be determined. This solution will then be ready to be implemented in all future emergencies, and it will be communicated to all HRD locations and the humanitarian community alike.

Behind the Scenes
